case_name: State of Bombay v. the respondents

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 269 of 1962 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 269 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated October 5, 1959 of Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 712 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 5, 1959 of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 712 of 1955.

facts.text: Four respondents are owners of certain agricultural lands in Deokhope in Taluka Palghar in Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: The four respondents are the owner of certain agricultural lands in Deokhope in Taluka Palghar in Maharashtra.

facts.text: Notice served by appellant State of Bombay (Maharashtra) on 23rd June 1951 to respondents about lands fallow since 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: On the 23rd June, 1951, a numberice was served by the appellant, State of Bombay  number Maharashtra , inviting the attention of the respondents to the fact that the agricultural lands of which they were the owners had remained fallow since 1948-49,

facts.text: Notice intimated State would resume management of lands under s.65 unless respondents cultivated in following season.

anchor.surface_text: and intimating to them that the appellant State would resume management of the said lands under s. 65 of the Act unless the respondents took steps to bring them under cultivation in the following agricultural season.

facts.text: Enquiry made under orders of Dy. Collector resulting in order on 30th December 1951 under s.65 to resume lands by Government.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that later, an enquiry was made under the orders of the Dy. Collector as a result of which on the 30th December, 1951, he passed an order under s. 65 directing that the lands should be resumed by the Government for cultivation.

facts.text: About 8 acres and 30 gunthas of land released to respondents after representations as they took steps to cultivate.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, representations were made by the respondents to the Dy. Collector as a result of which about 8 acres and 30 ghunthas of land were released on the ground that the owners had taken steps to cultivate that portion of the lands

facts.text: Respondent No.1 applied to Collector on 24th March 1952, application rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, respondent No. 1 approached the Collector by his application dated 24th March, 1952. This application was, however, rejected.

facts.text: Respondents moved Revenue Department, effort failed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then moved the Revenue Department, but that effort also failed.

facts.text: Suit filed by respondents on 23rd December 1953 for declaration that Dy. Collector order of 30 Dec 1951 illegal and void, possession and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: That is why the present suit was filed by them on the 23rd December, 1953 for a declaration that the order passed by the Dy. Collector on the 30th December, 1951 was illegal and void, and that it companyld number dispossess them of the lands which belonged to them.

facts.text: Appellant disputed suit, claimed barred under s.63 and s.85 of Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant disputed the respondents claim. It urged that the suit as framed was barred under S. 63  I   and s. 85 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant averred requisite enquiry duly made and impugned order passed in accordance with Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, the appellant challenged the companyrectness of the allegations made by the respondents. It was averred by the appellant that the requisite enquiry had been duly and properly made and the impunged order was passed in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Trial Judge upheld appellant contentions, suit barred by ss.65(1) and 85, declaration not null, provisions valid, enquiry proper, suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge who framed appropriate issues on these pleadings, in the main upheld the companytentions raised by the appellant. In his opinion, the present suit was barred by sections 65  1  and 85 of the Act. He also held that the declaration made by the Dy. Collector was number null and void.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then carried the matter before the High Court by an appeal,

facts.text: High Court upheld contention that delegation of duty to enquire under s.65(1) read with s.83 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has upheld the second of these companytentions. It has found that on a fair and reasonable companystruction of s. 65 1  read with s. 83, the appellant companyld delegate its powers prescribed by s. 65 1 , but companyld number delegate its duty incidental to the exercise of the said power.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court decree, decreed respondents' suit, ordered possession and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: That is why the decree passed by the trial Court has been reversed on this ground and the respondents suit has been decreed. Consistently with this decision, an appropriate order has been passed in regard to the delivery of possession and the payment of mesne profits

facts.text: Enquiry under s.65 made by Talathi and Mamlatdar, not by Dy. Collector.

anchor.surface_text: He argued that since the enquiry was made by the Talathi and the Mamlatdar under s. 65 and number by the Dy. Collector, the declaration made by the Dy. Collector was invalid.

facts.text: Supreme Court held delegation under s.83 includes duty incidental to power under s.65(1).

anchor.surface_text: Section 83 in terms authorises delegation by the State Government to any of its officers of the specified status and the delegation can be in respect of all or any of the powers companyferred on the State Government by the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Maharashtra Legislature amended s.83 via Section 29A of Amending Act deeming delegations valid from 31 Oct 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a result of the decision of the High Court in the present case, the Maharashtra Legislature thought it prudent to make the necessary amendment in s. 83 of the Act. Section 29 a  of the Amending Act provides that for the words powers companyferred the words Powers companyferred or duties impose shall be

facts.text: Dy. Collector directed subordinates Talathi and Mamlatdar to collect material for enquiry, not delegation.

anchor.surface_text: All that the Dy. Collector has done in the present case is to direct his subordinate officers to companylect material relevant to the purpose of the enquiry. The Talathi went on the spot and ascertained as to whether the respondents lands were lying fallow for the requisite period.

facts.text: Lands had remained uncultivated for two consecutive years as per s.65(1).

anchor.surface_text: inviting the attention of the respondents to the fact that the agricultural lands of which they were the owners had remained fallow since 1948-49,

facts.text: Trial court rejected respondents' plea against validity of ss.65,66 vis-a-vis Articles 19 and 31.

anchor.surface_text: The plea raised by the respondents against the validity of the statutory provisions companytained in sections 65 66 of the Act was rejected by him, because he thought that the said sections did number companytravene the provisions of Articles 19 and 31 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court found lands not 'lands' as defined by Act - contention raised by respondents.

facts.text: Enquiry held by Dy. Collector himself after receiving reports from subordinates.

anchor.surface_text: After the material was thus companylected, he examined the material himself, held the enquiry and came to companyclusion that the lands had remained fallow and uncultivated for the requisite period.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees; delegation includes incidental duty.

arguments.claim: s.83 authorizes delegation of powers; authority to delegate meaningless if duty to hold enquiry precedent cannot be delegated; power inseparable from enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Section 83 in terms authorises delegation by the State Government to any of its officers of the specified status and the delegation can be in respect of all or any of the powers conferred on the State Government by the provisions of the Act. Now, it seems to us that the authority to delegate all or any of the powers which is expressly conferred on the State Government by s. 83 would be rendered almost meaningless if the duty to hold an enquiry as a condition precedent for the exercise of the said authority cannot be delegated.

arguments.claim: Power and duty under s.65(1) interwoven, cannot split; delegation includes both (citing Privy Council precedent).

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we may usefully refer to the decision of the Privy Council in Edward Liso Mungoni v. Attorney-General of Northern Rhodesia 1 . In that case... the power and the duty under reg. 16 1  were so interwoven that it was number possible to split the one from the other... power coupled with a duty.

arguments.claim: Enquiry made by Talathi and Mamlatdar not Dy. Collector, so declaration invalid (sub-delegation).

anchor.surface_text: Realising the infirmity in the view taken by the High Court, Mr. Pathak attempted to support the decision of the High Court on another ground. He argued that since the enquiry was made by the Talathi and the Mamlatdar under s. 65 and number by the Dy. Collector, the declaration made by the Dy. Collector was invalid.

arguments.court_reasoning: No sub-delegation; subordinates collected material, Dy. Collector held enquiry himself.

arguments.claim: Delegate cannot delegate (delegatus non potest delegare), but no delegation by delegate here; Dy. Collector directed subordinates to collect material, examined it himself and held enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that a delegate who has received the authority from the principal cannot, in turn, delegate his own authority to a delegate of his own, but there is hardly any question of delegation by a delegate in the present case. All that the Dy. Collector has done in the present case is to direct his subordinate officers to collect material relevant to the purpose of the enquiry.

arguments.claim: English case Allingham distinguished; no delegation to hold enquiry, just material collection.

anchor.surface_text: We do number see how this case can assist Mr. Pathaks argument in the appeal before us, because there has been number delegation to hold an enquiry as such. What the Dy. Collector has done in the present proceedings is number to delegate his authority to hold an enquiry, but to get the material necessary for the enquiry collected by his subordinate officers.

arguments.claim: Grievance against propriety or reasonableness of enquiry not justified.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge also found that the grievance made by the respondents against the propriety or reasonableness of the enquiry made prior to the passing of the impunged order was number justified.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e himself, or the recording of the evidence and the actual inspection on the spot can be left to some subordinate officer. The report of such local in

holdings.text: On a fair and reasonable construction of s. 83 it must be held to authorise the delegation not only of the powers mentioned by it, but also of duties or functions which are incidental to the exercise of the powers and are integrally connected with them.

anchor.surface_text: we are satisfied that on a fair and reasonable construction of s. 83 it must be held to authorise the delegation not only of the powers mentioned by it, but also of duties or functions which are incidental to the exercise of the powers and are integrally connected with them. In this connection, we may usefully refer to the decision of the Privy Council in Edward Liso Mungoni v. Attorney-General of Northern Rhodesia 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delegation of power under s.83 would be meaningless if excluding precondition enquiry duty; power inseparable from incidental duty, supported by Privy Council precedent on interwoven power and duty.

holdings.text: There is no delegation by a delegate in the present case; the Dy. Collector merely directed subordinates to collect material relevant to the enquiry, examined it himself, held the enquiry, and made the declaration.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that a delegate who has received the authority from the principal cannot, in turn, delegate his own authority to a delegate of his own, but there is hardly any question of delegation by a delegate in the present case. All that the Dy. Collector has done in the present case is to direct his subordinate officers to collect material relevant to the purpose of the enquiry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subordinates collected factual material (spot inspection, reports); Dy. Collector personally examined material, held enquiry, and decided; no sub-delegation of decision-making authority; distinguishes English precedent.

holdings.text: The impugned declaration under s.65 by the Dy. Collector is valid as preceded by proper enquiry without invalid delegation.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the English decision on which Mr. Pathak relies does not assist him in the present case. This contention appears to have been raised before the High Court and has been rejected by it and, we think, rightly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying interpretation of s.65 r/w s.83 to facts: valid delegation to Dy. Collector, no sub-delegation, enquiry conducted properly by delegate.

holdings.text: We do not propose to express any opinion on whether there is an appeal against the enquiry and conclusion under s.86 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We do not propose to express any opinion on this part of the reasoning adopted by the High Court that will depend upon the construction of s. 86 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not necessary for decision; depends on separate construction of s.86.

precedents.citation: Edward Liso Mungoni v. Attorney-General of Northern Rhodesia 1

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection, we may usefully refer to the decision of the Privy Council in Edward Liso Mungoni v. Attorney-General of Northern Rhodesia 1 . In that case, in dealing with a similar question under regulation 16 1  of the Emergency Powers Regulations, 1956 of Northern Rhodesia, made by the Acting Governor of Northern Rhodesia under his statutory powers, the Privy Council has held that the power and the duty under reg. 16 1  were so interwoven that it was number possible to split the one from the other so as to put the duty on one person and the power in another the regulation companytained number so much a duty, but rather a power companypled with a duty, and he who exercised the power bad to carry out the duty.

precedents.case_name: Edward Liso Mungoni v. Attorney-General of Northern Rhodesia
precedents.cited_proposition: Power and duty in delegation are interwoven and cannot be split; delegation includes both power and incidental duty
precedents.cited_holding: the power and the duty under reg. 16(1) were so interwoven that it was not possible to split the one from the other so as to put the duty on one person and the power in another; regulation contained not so much a duty, but rather a power coupled with a duty

precedents.citation: Allingham and anr. Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of his argument, Mr. Pathak has relied on a decision of the Kings Bench Division in Allingham and anr. Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries 1 . In that case, the Court held that on the principle of delegatus number potest delegare, the Committee exercising its powers under reg. 62 1  companyld number delegate its powers to determine the land to be cultivated to its officers and, therefore, the numberice issued in that behalf was ineffective and numbercompliance with it was number an offence.

precedents.case_name: Allingham v. Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries
precedents.cited_proposition: delegatus non potest delegare - delegate cannot further delegate authority
precedents.cited_holding: the Committee exercising its powers under reg. 62(1) could not delegate its powers to determine the land to be cultivated to its officers

anchor.surface_text: we are satisfied that on a fair and reasonable construction of s. 83 it must be held to authorise the delegation not only of the powers mentioned by it, but also of duties or functions which are incidental to the exercise of the powers and are integrally connected with them. In this connection, we may usefully refer to the decision of the Privy Council in Edward Liso Mungoni v. Attorney-General of Northern Rhodesia 1 .

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that a delegate who has received the authority from the principal cannot, in turn, delegate his own authority to a delegate of his own, but there is hardly any question of delegation by a delegate in the present case. All that the Dy. Collector has done in the present case is to direct his subordinate officers to collect material relevant to the purpose of the enquiry.
Mr. Patwardhan contends that the view taken by the High Court is plainly erroneous and we are satisfied that this contention is well-founded.

edges.explanation: Holding finds no sub-delegation, distinguishing Allingham precedent where further delegation occurred.
